cluster_relations.rel_desc: Some caterpillars employ twig mimicry as a camouflage strategy.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: applies to some caterpillars, not all

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Some caterpillars use leaf mimicry to camouflage themselves.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: applies to some caterpillars, not all

cluster_relations.rel_desc: During the adult stage, butterflies focus on finding a mate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism employs a specific camouflage or mimicry adaptation as an anti-predator strategy.
args.justification: Both relations link caterpillars to specific camouflage/mimicry strategies (twig mimicry, leaf mimicry) used to avoid detection by predators; they share the same behavioral predicate semantics and differ only in the type of adaptation (object).

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism engages in mate-searching behavior directed toward a reproductive partner.
args.justification: The relation describes the adult butterfly life stage focusing on finding a mate, which is best captured as a directed mating-search behavior from the adult stage to a mate.
Both relations describe behavioral strategies used by caterpillars to avoid predation (camouflage/mimicry), fitting a shared class for anti-predator behaviors.
The behavior is specifically mate-seeking for reproduction, which is distinct from anti-predator strategies and fits a class for reproductive behaviors.
All three relations describe goal-directed behaviors or actions of organisms (camouflage use and mate seeking), which fall under a broad behavioral/agency-oriented group.

Both relations describe behavioral strategies used by caterpillars to avoid predation (camouflage/mimicry), fitting a shared class for anti-predator behaviors.
